boardgame.name: Galaxy Explorer: The Duel
boardgame.description:
Galaxy Explorer - The Duel


OVERVIEW

Galaxy Explorer The Duel is a dice rolling game where two players engage in space combat controlling one faction composed of a motherships supported by a fleet of squadrons. The mothership is obtained assembling 9 cards (poker size) where 6 cards represent an area of the mothership and the other 3 cards represent a Repair Bay, a Death Zone and a Damage Tracker. Squadrons come in smaller size cards. Galaxy Explorer The Duel is a dice rolling and worker placement game with a simple and quick gameplay.

During your turn you will assign crew to mothership areas to perform certain actions, you will spend deuterium to build up your fleet and improve your technology, possibly you will send assaulting squadron against the enemy mothership and finally you will fire at the enemy and will repair damage.



SCOPE OF THE GAME

The scope of the game is to be the first to destroy 3 main areas of the opponent’s mothership at which point the game ends immediately.



COMPONENTS

18 Mothership cards (poker size)
40 Squadron cards (mini deck)
14 Repair-ship cards (mini deck)
8 Technology cards (mini deck)
5 Red dice (crew)
5 Blue dice (crew)
1 Black die for activation and check rolls
8 Red cubes to track damage on the mothership areas
8 Blue cubes to track damage on the mothership areas
2 White cubes (8mm) to track deuterium
5 Lightning Bolts (damage tokens)



SOLO VERSION

This game can also be played solo.



WEBSITE

GalaxyExplorer

—description from the designer

boardgame.name: City at the Center of the Earth (Savage Worlds)
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

Since inventors Edison and Armstrong set out on their first journey to Mars in 1870, mankind has been enthused by the worlds lying beyond the Ether, and nations and enterprises, inventors and explorers have ventured into the depths of space. German inventor Elke Eggers, however, has no interest in going up. Driven by her memories of the fantastic tales her grandfather Ansgar used to tell her about underground civilizations, she has dedicated her life to seeking ways to voyage underground and find the mysterious City at the Center of the Earth.

This adventure is set on Earth and—in particular—inside it. On an adventurous journey à la Jules Verne’s Journey to the Center of the Earth and in particular Edgar Rice Burrough’s Pellucidar novels, the characters join Elke Eggers in her giant Mole Drill, digging its way towards the Earth’s core. But sabotage and unknown threats make the voyage challenging and dangerous. Will they reach the mysterious city Elke Egger is convinced exists down there? And if so, which mysteries and secrets await the adventurers there? What creatures live in the gigantic caverns deep down in the center of the Earth? And, where do the inhabitants—and possibly even builders—of this ‘World beneath the World’ come from?

The adventurers can be of any nationality, even if the starting point of the journey is set in the German Empire. The events in this adventure challenge various character archetypes with tasks matching their expertise: Academics, Scientists, and Explorers are best suited for this endeavor, of course, but Engineers, Mechanics, or Soldiers will be useful as well.

This adventure is written for the Savage Worlds Version of the Space:1889 RPG.

boardgame.name: Miniquest
boardgame.description:
Miniquest is a cooperative game in which players play the role of heroes who have been summoned by the King in a moment of despair. Argo the dragon is back and his armies have invaded the kingdom. Gosu, Jeju, Mana, and Ryu are the King's last hope!

Together heroes will try to stop the assaults of the Dwarves, the Goblins, the One-Eyed Ogres, the Undead, and sometimes Argo himself!

Heroes must defend the regions attacked by Argo's armies by placing their character standee on the card representing the region. Each turn, a player draws a card from the deck to determine which region they must defend. To repel an attack, heroes roll a die and use their special abilities by gaining XP. If they do not defend efficiently, the threat to see the kingdom falling under the claws of Argo will grow…

Argo wins the game if the deck runs out of cards, if the threat is too high, or if he defeats the heroes four or five times.

Heroes win the game if they gain enough prestige to force Argo to abandon the war, but prestige is not easily gained: Only a victory in combat against Argo or his strongest armies will reward the heroes with prestige!

boardgame.name: Judgy McJudgerson
boardgame.description:
Judgy McJudgerson: The game all humans are good at.

We’re constantly judging people based on how their face looks. (Don’t even act like you don’t.) Now there’s a party game that turns those hilarious and, let’s face it, totally true stereotypes into hours of entertainment. Now you and your friends can sit around judging and laughing at other people that aren’t in the room.

Here’s how it works:

The judge picks a random person’s face from the yellow deck.
Everyone plays a brutal Judgement Card from their hand.
The judge selects the most accurate and offensive insult.

In a country more divided than ever, we might as well play a game that divides it just a little bit more.

—description from the publisher

boardgame.name: Guide to Lairs
boardgame.description:
From publisher blurb:

A world of ghosts and ghouls awaits the unwary investigator who is scared of the dark!

Dark and brooding woods, where trails appear and disappear at will and the undergrowth grows suddenly thicker once a traveller has left the path. Abandoned castles, where those who sleep within suffer terrible nightmares of grasping hands emerging from darkness. Ancient battlefields, where those who tarry too long develop feelings of despair or belligerence.

These places are known among the Leagues of Adventure as lairs, and this supplement — reproduced from a lengthy lecture by the Ghost Club — provides Gamemasters with rules and advice for creating and using them.

Inside you’ll find a range of devilish powers for turning ordinary sites into places of terror, sample lairs, and a bonus chapter with more occult relics.

boardgame.name: Ponies
boardgame.description:
Ponies is a horse racing game with dice. Seven dice are included with the game, 6 with letters and 1 normal die. Players start with an equal amount of money (in 1, 5, 10, 20 and 50 unit demoninations) and all start with a 5 unit in the stake fund.

Each players take turns at one roll of all seven dice. The following word combinations are possible:

WIN - Player takes all units in stake. This then starts a new game.
PLACE - Player collects 1/2 of the units in the stake.
SHOW - Player collects 1/3 of the units in the stake.
LEAD - Player collects 10 times the number of units indicated by nunber on normal die from the stake.
PACE or RACE - Player collects 5 times the number of units indicated by number on the normal die from the stake.
REAR - Player neither collects or donates.
If none of the above words appear on role, player then donates number of units indicated on the normal die to the stake.

Player can never collect more money than is in the stake. When there is no more money in the stake, all players donate five unites apiece to the stake.

Game continues until someone gets WIN.

Alternate game play: Only play with rules for WIN, PLACE or SHOW.

—user summary

boardgame.name: Button Men: Beat People Up – Doctor Lucky Promo Card
boardgame.description:
This card features "Doctor J. Robert Lucky" from Kill Doctor Lucky.

Doctor Lucky has a special ability as well as a strange dice size.

Doctor's Luck: If Doctor Lucky has only one die, you must flip a coin after attacking it. If the flip is heads, the die remains in play.

Size 19.5 Die: Use a d20, but if the roll is 20, flip a coin. If the flip is heads, treat it as a value of 19.5. Otherwise, reroll it.

This promo card was distributed in Game Trade Magazine #214 (December 2017).

boardgame.name: Blood on the Clocktower
boardgame.description:
In the quiet village of Ravenswood Bluff, ‌a demon walks amongst you...

During a hellish thunderstorm, on the stroke of midnight, there echoes a bone-chilling scream. The townsfolk rush to investigate and find the town storyteller murdered, their body impaled on the hands of the clocktower, blood dripping onto the cobblestones below. A Demon is on the loose, murdering by night and disguised in human form by day. Some have scraps of information. Others have abilities that fight the evil or protect the innocent. But the Demon and its evil minions are spreading lies to confuse and breed suspicion. Will the good townsfolk put the puzzle together in time to execute the true demon and save themselves? Or will evil overrun this once peaceful village?

Blood on the Clocktower is a bluffing game enjoyed by 5 to 20 players on opposing teams of Good and Evil, overseen by a Storyteller player who conducts the action and makes crucial decisions. The goal of the game is to successfully deduce and execute the demons before they outnumber the townfolk.

During a 'day' phase players socialize openly and whisper privately to trade knowledge or spread lies, culminating in a player's execution if a majority suspects them of being Evil. Of a 'night' time, players close their eyes and are woken one at a time by the Storyteller to gather information, spread mischief, or kill.

The Storyteller uses the game's intricate playing pieces to guide each game, leaving others free to play without a table or board. Players stay in the thick of the action to the very end even if their characters are killed, haunting Ravenswood Bluff as ghosts trying to win from beyond the grave.

If you arrive late to a game, you can enter after it's started as a powerful Traveller character with unusual talents and questionable allegiances. Each character comes with their own special ability and no two players in a game are ever the same character.

boardgame.name: Ghost Files: The Face of Guilt
boardgame.description:
The people of Boston are shocked by the recent series of mysterious murders and you are given a task of bringing the culprit to justice as fast as possible. As the police detective Emily Meyer you are facing the task of solving the case of a mysterious “Guilty Man”. Using police techniques, you will follow the trail of the suspect while solving riddles and collecting fingerprints as well as different samples from crime scenes. When your investigation unexpectedly leads to the place between life and death, you will face the biggest challenge of your life. Will your detective skills be enough to let you survive in the afterlife? Can you solve the case? Test yourself in the world of ghosts, dark riddles, locks and enigmas. Use the help of a psychic to find your way back to the world and solve the case of the serial killer.

Source: The Publisher Website.

Performance is based on the interaction of actual batting and pitching data. Game can be played by one or two players with the computer acting as second player when desired. Each includes about 50 players allowing nearly an infinite number of roster and lineup possibilities.

$14.95

boardgame.name: Invaders from Outer Space
boardgame.description:
User summary

Invaders from Outer Space is a simple arcade style game pitting the player against encroaching aliens. The player uses a joystick to aim and fire "base" weapons against an invading fleet of saucers. The base can sustain three levels of incremental damage before the game ends. Player firepower decreases with increasing damage level.

The program source code was written by David H. Markley and published in Compute!, Issue 11, April 1981.

boardgame.name: Battle Tanks
boardgame.description:
This is a game based on 8-bit video game "Battle City".

In this game players control their tanks on the modular board and strive to destroy bot-tanks and capture the eagle to get victory points. The game is continious until three eagles were captures or one player scored 5 points more than the next one after him.

Each player own his deck and takes cards in a hand from it. To perform actions players play cards from hand - so they can rotation and move their tanks.
First, players choose cards for first and second maneuver facedown. It can be any namber of rotation cards, but only one move action.
Now start with the first player and continue the clockwise players perform their first maneuver, then move all the bot-tanks by special rules. When all tanks moved, they shoot on target. Player's tank can shoot on the brick wall or any other tanks. Bot-tanks can shoot only at player's tank. All shoot is simultaneously.
If a player's tank shoot at bot-tank, they is destroy now, and player get a victory point. Now a bonus tile is placed On a battlefield.
If the player's tank is shot, player must discard 2 cards. If he can not, his tank is destroyed until this round ends.
After the first maneuver is performed, players perform second maneuver. After second maneuver a round is ending and players prepare to the next round.

—user summmary

boardgame.name: Streets and Alleys
boardgame.description: Streets and Alleys is a solitaire card game using a traditional deck of 52 cards. The goal of the game is to build up four foundations in suit from ace to king. The tableau is laid out in four columns of seven and four columns of six cards. The top card of each column is available to play. The card may be moved to the foundation if fits or to build a tableau pile down regardless of suit. Empty tableaus can be filled with any card. Cards may be only moved one at a time.

boardgame.name: 100 Female Luchadora Names
boardgame.description:
Publisher Blurb:

Lucha libre is a professional wrestling game that originated in Mexico. Its competitors, or luchadoras, are known for the highly decorative masks that many of them wear, often with their true identities hidden by both the masks and their names.

This is a list of 100 different female names, or perhaps titles, inspired by the sport of lucha libre. They are in Spanish with English translations. These names could be used for professional wrestlers in a wrestling RPG, and some are more suitable for the "rudos" or "bad guys" of Mexican wrestling. The names could even used for superheroes and supervillains in another type of game.

Here is a sample result:

49. La Hija de la Muerte - Death's Daughter

boardgame.name: The Bottled Imp Game
boardgame.description:
The Bottled Imp Game is a card game for 2-6 players. The object of the game is to be the player holding the Bottled Imp Card at the end of the game's allotted 8 rounds.

Each player begins the game with 5 cards in their hand. One of the players (nobody else knows who) has the Bottled Imp card. The number of cards they are permitted to hold is denoted by their 'Life Dice', it begins at 5, but can go up or down from 2 to 7.

In each round players get a turn to lay any number of one type of card, then draw back up to their allotted hand size. The card types and their affects are:

Dagger = Reduce and opponents Life Dice
Pie and Ale = Increase your own life dice
Spyglass = Look at an opponent's hand
Lockpick = Blindly take one card from an opponent's hand
Wild/Coins = Wild card
Bottled Imp = Win the game

After each player has taken a turn the round is over. This happens 8 times, recorded on a D8, then the game is over. The player holding the Bottled Imp Card at this point is the winner.

Sounds simple, but in reality keeping track of where you think the Imp is and timing when to make a play for it provides some very interesting decisions and a tense atmosphere.

A good game for a party or warm up.

—description from the publisher
